Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding gene expression changes leading to human diseases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many diseases, including cancer, autoimmune disorders, and others are triggered by unusual perturbations in the expression of certain genes. The interactions between these genes and other present in the human genome are poorly understood, and it is not known how these interactions may be changed over time due to abnormal gene expression. This project will focus on computationally detecting perturbations that may lead to disease using publically available gene expression data from human cancer cell lines, with the eventual goal of confirming these results using experimental cell culture. This research will be conducted in collaboration with the Dr. Hsueh Fen Juan's laboratory at the National Taiwan University due to their expertise in computational and experimental analysis of human disease. This research will help to understand how these diseases begin and sustain themselves while revealing possible new targets for pharmaceutical treatments.

The principal goal of this research is evaluate the transcriptional network motifs that drive the initial formation of cancerous or other diseased cells, and then discover how these motifs depend on the underlying transcriptional context of a given cell line. Both tissue and time dependence of these motifs will be considered to better understand the transition from normal to diseased cells. This project will also increase the visibility of a combined computational and experimental approach to biological problems. All new gene expression data will be stored in the National Center of Biotechnology Information Gene Expression Omnibus. Cell lines created for experimental validation will be distributed through cell line repositories for use by other researchers. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project attempted to use human cancer gene expression data to identify malfunctioning regulatory motifs, which help to stabilize or shift the expression of groups of genes as part of human development. Often, these motifs are disrupted in cancers, as they control key cellular processes such as cell profileration, immortality, and many others. The PI's efforts were mainly devoted to developing software for simulating gene expression changes arising from alterations in key transcriptional and translational kinetic parameters in proteins involved with regulatory motifs. A significant focus was also developing an algorithmic package for converting raw experimental data into computational models; this process allowed researchers in the host lab to examine how manually implemented mutations affected their observed gene expression data in a rigorous fashion.

The broader societal impacts of this project are numerous; given the mortality and morbidity rate associated with cancer in the USA and Taiwan, progress towards understanding regulatory motif perturbations may uncover novel treatment routes that can be used to convert cancerous tissue into less aggressive or benign diseases. A significant future decrease in health care costs and suffering may therefore follow from research in this area. This grant also allowed for effective cultural interchange and cross-border mentoring.


Last Modified: 08/23/2015
Modified by: James Winkler
